cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Michael J Fox travels back to which year in the Wild West in the 1990 film ‘Back To The Future Part III’?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
In the 1990 film "Back to the Future Part III," Michael J. Fox's character, Marty McFly, travels back to the year 1885. This is established in the film's plot, where Marty goes to rescue Doc Brown, who is stuck in the Wild West during that time period. The film showcases various elements of the Wild West, including cowboys, saloons, and the challenges of that era.

Answer:
1885

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Michael J Fox travels back to which year in the Wild West in the 1990 film ‘Back To The Future Part III’?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The origins of the western theme for "Back to the Future Part III" lie in the production of the original film. During filming for the original, director Zemeckis asked Michael J. Fox what time period he would like to see. Fox replied that he wanted to visit the Old West and meet cowboys. Zemeckis and writer/producer Bob Gale were intrigued by the idea, but held it off until "Part III". Rather than use existing sets, the filmmakers built the 1885 Hill Valley from scratch. The western scenes were filmed on location in Monument Valley. Some of the location shooting for the 1885 Hill Valley was done in Jamestown, California, and on a purpose-built set at the Red Hills Ranch near Sonora, California. Some of the train scenes were filmed at Railtown 1897 State Historic Park, a heritage line in Jamestown. Whereas the original film played to a more materialistic idea of success, Zemeckis considered "Part III" more of a "human journey" with spiritual overtones.\n', 'Back to the Future Part III is a 1990 American science fiction film and the third and final installment of the "Back to the Future" trilogy. The film was directed by Robert Zemeckis, and stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Mary Steenburgen, Thomas F. Wilson and Lea Thompson. The film continues immediately following "Back to the Future Part II" (1989); while stranded in 1955 during his time travel adventures, Marty McFly (Fox) discovers that his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown (Lloyd), trapped in 1885, was killed by Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen (Wilson), Biff\'s great-grandfather. Marty travels to 1885 to rescue Doc and return once again to 1985, but matters are complicated when Doc falls in love with schoolteacher Clara Clayton (Steenburgen).\n', 'The "Back to the Future" franchise is an American science fiction–adventure comedy film series written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, produced by Bob Gale and Neil Canton for Steven Spielberg\'s Amblin Entertainment, and distributed by Universal Pictures. The franchise follows the adventures of a high school student, Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox), and an eccentric scientist, Dr. Emmett L. Brown (Christopher Lloyd), as they use a DeLorean time machine to time travel to different periods in the history of Hill Valley, California.\n', 'Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Bob Gale. It is the sequel to the 1985 film "Back to the Future" and the second installment in the "Back to the Future" trilogy. The film stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Thomas F. Wilson, and Lea Thompson. The film follows Marty McFly (Fox) and his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown (Lloyd) as they travel from 1985 to 2015 to prevent Marty\'s son from sabotaging the McFly family\'s future; when their arch-nemesis Biff Tannen (Wilson) steals Doc\'s DeLorean time machine and uses it to alter history for his benefit, the duo must return to 1955 to restore the timeline.\n', 'BULLET::::- In "Back to the Future Part III" (1990), Marty McFly drives from 1955 to 1885 from a drive-in theatre set at the Valley\'s base.\n', 'In "Back to the Future Part III", Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) while time-travelling to the Wild West, finds amusement in seeing the word "Frisbie" at the bottom of a pie plate. He later throws the plate at a derringer held by outlaw Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen (Thomas F. Wilson), foiling his attempt to shoot Doctor Emmett Brown (Christopher Lloyd).\n', 'On the October 21, 2015, episode of "Jimmy Kimmel Live", Lloyd and Michael J. Fox appeared in a "Back to the Future" skit to commemorate the date in the second installment of the movie trilogy.\n', 'Back to the Future is a 1985 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Zemeckis and Bob Gale. It stars Michael J. Fox as teenager Marty McFly, who accidentally travels back in time from 1985 to 1955, where he meets his future parents and becomes his mother\'s romantic interest. Christopher Lloyd portrays the eccentric scientist Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown, inventor of the time-traveling DeLorean, who helps Marty repair history and return to 1985. The cast also includes Lea Thompson as Marty\'s mother Lorraine, Crispin Glover as his father George, and Thomas F. Wilson as Biff Tannen, Marty and George\'s arch-nemesis.\n', '"Part II" was released on November 22, 1989, to mixed reviews and similar financial success as the original, finishing as the third highest-grossing film of the year worldwide. The film continues directly from the ending of "Back to the Future" and follows Marty and Doc as they travel into the future of 2015, an alternative 1985, and 1955 where Marty must repair the future while avoiding his past self from the original film. "Part II" became notable for its 2015 setting and predictions of technology such as hoverboards.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1990 "Back to the Future Part III" as George Douglas McFly\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about the year Michael J. Fox travels back to in "Back to the Future Part III," we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. 

### Extracted Content:

1. **Time Period of Travel**:
   - The film features Marty McFly traveling to **1885**. This is explicitly mentioned in the second passage, which states that Marty discovers Doc Brown is trapped in 1885 and travels there to rescue him.

2. **Setting and Theme**:
   - The film is set in the **Wild West**, which is a significant thematic element. The first passage discusses how the western theme was inspired by Michael J. Fox's desire to meet cowboys, indicating a creative decision that shaped the film's narrative.

3. **Production Details**:
   - The filmmakers built the **1885 Hill Valley** from scratch, rather than using existing sets. This detail emphasizes the effort put into creating an authentic Wild West atmosphere, which is crucial for the film's setting.

4. **Character Dynamics**:
   - The film includes characters like **Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen**, who poses a threat to Doc Brown, and Clara Clayton, who becomes a love interest for Doc. This adds emotional stakes to the narrative, as Marty not only has to rescue Doc but also navigate the complexities of Doc's new life in the past.

5. **Film Context**:
   - "Back to the Future Part III" is the third installment of a trilogy that follows the adventures of Marty McFly and Doc Brown as they use a DeLorean time machine to travel to various periods in Hill Valley's history. This context helps to understand the continuity of the story and the significance of the time travel element.

### Role of Extracted Content:

- **Temporal Context**: Knowing that Marty travels to 1885 is crucial for answering the question. It situates the film within a specific historical context, which is essential for understanding the narrative and character interactions.
  
- **Thematic Understanding**: The Wild West setting is not just a backdrop; it influences the characters' actions and the plot's direction. Understanding this theme helps to appreciate the film's exploration of human relationships and moral dilemmas within a historical framework.

- **Character Relationships**: The dynamics between characters, particularly the conflict with Buford Tannen and Doc's relationship with Clara, enrich the story. This knowledge is important for grasping the emotional depth of the film and the stakes involved in Marty's journey.

- **Production Insight**: The effort to create a believable 1885 setting reflects the filmmakers' commitment to storytelling. This background enhances appreciation for the film's artistic choices and the immersive experience it aims to provide.

In summary, the extracted content provides essential background knowledge that enhances understanding of the film's plot, themes, and character dynamics, ultimately leading to a more informed answer to the question about the year Michael J. Fox travels back to in "Back to the Future Part III."

This is established in the film's plot, where Marty goes to rescue Doc Brown, who is stuck in the Wild West during that time period. 1885

The passages provided contain several key pieces of information about "Back to the Future Part III," which can enhance understanding of the film's context, plot, and significance within the franchise. Here’s a consolidated summary and analysis of the relevant content:

### Summary of Key Information

1. **Time Travel to 1885**: In "Back to the Future Part III," Michael J. Fox's character, Marty McFly, travels back to the year **1885**. This setting is significant as it represents the Wild West, a theme that was inspired by Fox's desire to meet cowboys during the production of the original film.

2. **Plot Continuation**: The film follows directly from the events of "Back to the Future Part II," where Marty discovers that his friend, Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown, is trapped in 1885 and is in danger of being killed by an outlaw named Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen. Marty’s mission is to rescue Doc and return to their original time, 1985.

3. **Filming Locations**: The filmmakers created a version of Hill Valley as it would have appeared in 1885, building sets from scratch rather than using existing ones. Key filming locations included Monument Valley and Jamestown, California, which helped to authentically portray the Wild West setting.

4. **Character Development**: The film explores themes of love and personal growth, particularly through Doc's relationship with schoolteacher Clara Clayton. This adds a layer of emotional depth to the narrative, contrasting with the more materialistic themes of the earlier films.

5. **Franchise Context**: "Back to the Future Part III" is the final installment of the trilogy, which overall follows the adventures of Marty McFly and Doc Brown as they navigate various time periods using a DeLorean time machine. The franchise is known for its blend of science fiction, adventure, and comedy.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents

- **Understanding the Setting**: Knowing that Marty travels to 1885 helps contextualize the film within the broader narrative of the trilogy. It highlights the filmmakers' creative choices in exploring different historical periods and genres, particularly the Western genre, which is rich with cultural significance.

- **Character Motivations**: The information about Marty’s mission to save Doc provides insight into the character dynamics and motivations, which are central to the emotional core of the film. Understanding these relationships enhances the viewer's appreciation of the story's stakes.

- **Cinematic Techniques**: The details about the filming locations and set design illustrate the effort put into creating an immersive experience for the audience. This knowledge can deepen appreciation for the production values and the filmmakers' commitment to authenticity.

- **Thematic Exploration**: Recognizing the shift in themes from materialism to personal journeys allows for a deeper analysis of the film’s message. It encourages viewers to consider how the characters evolve and what they learn through their experiences.

### Conclusion

By synthesizing this foundational and advanced knowledge, one gains a comprehensive understanding of "Back to the Future Part III." This understanding not only addresses the specific question about the year Marty travels to but also enriches the overall appreciation of the film's narrative, themes, and production. This holistic view encourages deeper engagement with the film and its place within the larger context of the trilogy and cinematic history.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In the 1990 film "Back to the Future Part III," Michael J. Fox portrays Marty McFly, who travels back to the year **1885**. This journey is a critical plot point, as Marty aims to rescue his friend, Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown, who is in danger of being killed by the outlaw Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen. The film's setting in the Wild West is significant not only for its cultural implications but also because it reflects the filmmakers' desire to explore different historical genres, inspired by Fox's interest in cowboys during the original film's production.

The film continues directly from "Back to the Future Part II," maintaining narrative continuity and character development. The stakes are heightened as Marty navigates the challenges of the Wild West, including encounters with cowboys and the lawlessness of the era. The filmmakers constructed a version of Hill Valley as it would have appeared in 1885, utilizing locations like Monument Valley and Jamestown, California, to authentically depict the Wild West environment.

Moreover, the film delves into themes of love and personal growth, particularly through Doc's relationship with Clara Clayton, which adds emotional depth to the story. This contrasts with the earlier films' more materialistic themes, showcasing character evolution and the importance of human connections.

Understanding the context of the film within the broader "Back to the Future" trilogy enhances appreciation for its narrative structure and thematic exploration. The trilogy is known for its unique blend of science fiction, adventure, and comedy, making it a significant part of cinematic history.

By synthesizing this foundational and advanced knowledge, one gains a comprehensive understanding of the film's plot, character motivations, and thematic depth. This holistic perspective encourages deeper engagement with the film and its cultural significance.

### Answer:
1885

The film continues directly from the ending of "Back to the Future" and follows Marty and Doc as they travel into the future of 2015, an alternative 1985, and 1955 where Marty must repair the future while avoiding his past self from the original film. "Part II" became notable for its 2015 setting and predictions of technology such as hoverboards.
', 'BULLET::::- 1990 "Back to the Future Part III" as George Douglas McFly
']

This motivation drives the plot and illustrates the causal relationship between Marty's actions and the events that unfold.

3. **Setting and Production**: The filmmakers created a version of Hill Valley set in 1885, indicating the effort to build a believable historical context. This aspect of production can be linked to the narrative's authenticity and the audience's immersion in the story.

4. **Character Relationships**: The film explores the relationship between Doc and Clara Clayton, a schoolteacher in 1885. This subplot adds emotional depth and complexity to the narrative, showcasing how personal relationships can influence decisions and actions.

5. **Cultural References**: Marty's amusement at seeing the word "Frisbie" on a pie plate connects the past with the present, highlighting how cultural artifacts can transcend time and influence character behavior.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Temporal Relationships**: Understanding that Marty travels to 1885 establishes a clear cause-and-effect relationship in the narrative. 5. **Cultural Continuity**: The reference to "Frisbie" serves as a bridge between different time periods, illustrating how cultural elements can influence character behavior across time. This can help the model recognize patterns of continuity and change in cultural contexts.

By consolidating these insights, the model can develop a more nuanced understanding of causal relationships in narratives, improving its ability to reason logically about character motivations, temporal dynamics, and the impact of setting on story development.

1885

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

In the 1990 film "Back to the Future Part III," Michael J. Fox portrays Marty McFly, who travels back to the year **1885**. This time travel is a critical plot point, as Marty aims to rescue his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown, who is in danger from an outlaw named Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen. The film's setting in the Wild West is characterized by elements such as cowboys, saloons, and the societal challenges of that era, which significantly influence the narrative.

1. **Temporal Context**: The year 1885 is pivotal as it establishes the historical backdrop against which the story unfolds. This context allows for exploration of themes such as friendship, bravery, and the clash between modernity and tradition.

2. **Character Motivation**: Marty's motivation to travel back is rooted in his loyalty to Doc. This relationship drives the plot forward and highlights the importance of friendship and sacrifice. Understanding this motivation helps in inferring why Marty makes certain decisions throughout the film.

3. **Setting and Authenticity**: The filmmakers' effort to recreate Hill Valley in 1885 adds authenticity to the narrative. This setting not only immerses the audience in the Wild West but also serves as a catalyst for character interactions and conflicts, illustrating how environment shapes behavior.

4. **Interpersonal Dynamics**: The subplot involving Doc and Clara Clayton enriches the narrative by introducing emotional stakes. Clara's presence influences Doc's decisions, showcasing how personal relationships can complicate and drive the plot.

5. **Cultural References**: The humorous moment when Marty sees "Frisbie" on a pie plate serves as a cultural link between the past and present. This highlights how cultural artifacts can influence character behavior and perceptions, bridging temporal divides.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Understanding Temporal Relationships**: Recognizing that Marty travels to 1885 establishes a clear cause-and-effect relationship, enhancing the model's ability to reason about how actions in one time period can affect outcomes in another.

2. **Inferring Character Motivations**: By analyzing Marty's motivations (to save Doc), the model can improve its inference skills regarding character actions based on their goals and the challenges they face, which is essential for logical reasoning in narratives.

3. **Setting as a Causal Factor**: The historical setting influences character interactions and plot developments. The model can learn to identify how environments shape narratives and character behavior, enhancing its causal reasoning capabilities.

4. **Understanding Interpersonal Dynamics**: The relationship between Doc and Clara introduces emotional causality, where personal connections influence decisions. This understanding can improve the model's ability to reason about how relationships impact actions and outcomes.

5. **Recognizing Cultural Continuity**: The reference to "Frisbie" illustrates how cultural elements can transcend time, helping the model recognize patterns of continuity and change across different contexts.

By integrating these insights, the model can develop a more nuanced understanding of causal relationships in narratives, improving its ability to reason logically about character motivations, temporal dynamics, and the impact of setting on story development.

### Answer:
1885

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Michael J Fox travels back to which year in the Wild West in the 1990 film ‘Back To The Future Part III’?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The origins of the western theme for "Back to the Future Part III" lie in the production of the original film. During filming for the original, director Zemeckis asked Michael J. Fox what time period he would like to see. Fox replied that he wanted to visit the Old West and meet cowboys. Zemeckis and writer/producer Bob Gale were intrigued by the idea, but held it off until "Part III". Rather than use existing sets, the filmmakers built the 1885 Hill Valley from scratch. The western scenes were filmed on location in Monument Valley. Some of the location shooting for the 1885 Hill Valley was done in Jamestown, California, and on a purpose-built set at the Red Hills Ranch near Sonora, California. Some of the train scenes were filmed at Railtown 1897 State Historic Park, a heritage line in Jamestown. Whereas the original film played to a more materialistic idea of success, Zemeckis considered "Part III" more of a "human journey" with spiritual overtones.\n', 'Back to the Future Part III is a 1990 American science fiction film and the third and final installment of the "Back to the Future" trilogy. The film was directed by Robert Zemeckis, and stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Mary Steenburgen, Thomas F. Wilson and Lea Thompson. The film continues immediately following "Back to the Future Part II" (1989); while stranded in 1955 during his time travel adventures, Marty McFly (Fox) discovers that his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown (Lloyd), trapped in 1885, was killed by Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen (Wilson), Biff\'s great-grandfather. Marty travels to 1885 to rescue Doc and return once again to 1985, but matters are complicated when Doc falls in love with schoolteacher Clara Clayton (Steenburgen).\n', 'The "Back to the Future" franchise is an American science fiction–adventure comedy film series written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, produced by Bob Gale and Neil Canton for Steven Spielberg\'s Amblin Entertainment, and distributed by Universal Pictures. The franchise follows the adventures of a high school student, Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox), and an eccentric scientist, Dr. Emmett L. Brown (Christopher Lloyd), as they use a DeLorean time machine to time travel to different periods in the history of Hill Valley, California.\n', 'Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Bob Gale. It is the sequel to the 1985 film "Back to the Future" and the second installment in the "Back to the Future" trilogy. The film stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Thomas F. Wilson, and Lea Thompson. The film follows Marty McFly (Fox) and his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown (Lloyd) as they travel from 1985 to 2015 to prevent Marty\'s son from sabotaging the McFly family\'s future; when their arch-nemesis Biff Tannen (Wilson) steals Doc\'s DeLorean time machine and uses it to alter history for his benefit, the duo must return to 1955 to restore the timeline.\n', 'BULLET::::- In "Back to the Future Part III" (1990), Marty McFly drives from 1955 to 1885 from a drive-in theatre set at the Valley\'s base.\n', 'In "Back to the Future Part III", Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) while time-travelling to the Wild West, finds amusement in seeing the word "Frisbie" at the bottom of a pie plate. He later throws the plate at a derringer held by outlaw Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen (Thomas F. Wilson), foiling his attempt to shoot Doctor Emmett Brown (Christopher Lloyd).\n', 'On the October 21, 2015, episode of "Jimmy Kimmel Live", Lloyd and Michael J. Fox appeared in a "Back to the Future" skit to commemorate the date in the second installment of the movie trilogy.\n', 'Back to the Future is a 1985 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Zemeckis and Bob Gale. It stars Michael J. Fox as teenager Marty McFly, who accidentally travels back in time from 1985 to 1955, where he meets his future parents and becomes his mother\'s romantic interest. Christopher Lloyd portrays the eccentric scientist Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown, inventor of the time-traveling DeLorean, who helps Marty repair history and return to 1985. The cast also includes Lea Thompson as Marty\'s mother Lorraine, Crispin Glover as his father George, and Thomas F. Wilson as Biff Tannen, Marty and George\'s arch-nemesis.\n', '"Part II" was released on November 22, 1989, to mixed reviews and similar financial success as the original, finishing as the third highest-grossing film of the year worldwide. The film continues directly from the ending of "Back to the Future" and follows Marty and Doc as they travel into the future of 2015, an alternative 1985, and 1955 where Marty must repair the future while avoiding his past self from the original film. "Part II" became notable for its 2015 setting and predictions of technology such as hoverboards.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1990 "Back to the Future Part III" as George Douglas McFly\n']

question_info.question: Michael J Fox travels back to which year in the Wild West in the 1990 film ‘Back To The Future Part III’?
passages:
The origins of the western theme for "Back to the Future Part III" lie in the production of the original film. During filming for the original, director Zemeckis asked Michael J. Fox what time period he would like to see. Fox replied that he wanted to visit the Old West and meet cowboys. Zemeckis and writer/producer Bob Gale were intrigued by the idea, but held it off until "Part III". Rather than use existing sets, the filmmakers built the 1885 Hill Valley from scratch. The western scenes were filmed on location in Monument Valley. Some of the location shooting for the 1885 Hill Valley was done in Jamestown, California, and on a purpose-built set at the Red Hills Ranch near Sonora, California. Some of the train scenes were filmed at Railtown 1897 State Historic Park, a heritage line in Jamestown. Whereas the original film played to a more materialistic idea of success, Zemeckis considered "Part III" more of a "human journey" with spiritual overtones.
Back to the Future Part III is a 1990 American science fiction film and the third and final installment of the "Back to the Future" trilogy. The film was directed by Robert Zemeckis, and stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Mary Steenburgen, Thomas F. Wilson and Lea Thompson. The film continues immediately following "Back to the Future Part II" (1989); while stranded in 1955 during his time travel adventures, Marty McFly (Fox) discovers that his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown (Lloyd), trapped in 1885, was killed by Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen (Wilson), Biff's great-grandfather. Marty travels to 1885 to rescue Doc and return once again to 1985, but matters are complicated when Doc falls in love with schoolteacher Clara Clayton (Steenburgen).
The "Back to the Future" franchise is an American science fiction–adventure comedy film series written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, produced by Bob Gale and Neil Canton for Steven Spielberg's Amblin Entertainment, and distributed by Universal Pictures. The franchise follows the adventures of a high school student, Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox), and an eccentric scientist, Dr. Emmett L. Brown (Christopher Lloyd), as they use a DeLorean time machine to time travel to different periods in the history of Hill Valley, California.
Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Bob Gale. It is the sequel to the 1985 film "Back to the Future" and the second installment in the "Back to the Future" trilogy. The film stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Thomas F. Wilson, and Lea Thompson. The film follows Marty McFly (Fox) and his friend Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown (Lloyd) as they travel from 1985 to 2015 to prevent Marty's son from sabotaging the McFly family's future; when their arch-nemesis Biff Tannen (Wilson) steals Doc's DeLorean time machine and uses it to alter history for his benefit, the duo must return to 1955 to restore the timeline.
BULLET::::- In "Back to the Future Part III" (1990), Marty McFly drives from 1955 to 1885 from a drive-in theatre set at the Valley's base.
In "Back to the Future Part III", Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) while time-travelling to the Wild West, finds amusement in seeing the word "Frisbie" at the bottom of a pie plate. He later throws the plate at a derringer held by outlaw Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen (Thomas F. Wilson), foiling his attempt to shoot Doctor Emmett Brown (Christopher Lloyd).
On the October 21, 2015, episode of "Jimmy Kimmel Live", Lloyd and Michael J. Fox appeared in a "Back to the Future" skit to commemorate the date in the second installment of the movie trilogy.
Back to the Future is a 1985 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Zemeckis and Bob Gale. It stars Michael J. Fox as teenager Marty McFly, who accidentally travels back in time from 1985 to 1955, where he meets his future parents and becomes his mother's romantic interest. Christopher Lloyd portrays the eccentric scientist Dr. Emmett "Doc" Brown, inventor of the time-traveling DeLorean, who helps Marty repair history and return to 1985. The cast also includes Lea Thompson as Marty's mother Lorraine, Crispin Glover as his father George, and Thomas F. Wilson as Biff Tannen, Marty and George's arch-nemesis.
"Part II" was released on November 22, 1989, to mixed reviews and similar financial success as the original, finishing as the third highest-grossing film of the year worldwide. The film continues directly from the ending of "Back to the Future" and follows Marty and Doc as they travel into the future of 2015, an alternative 1985, and 1955 where Marty must repair the future while avoiding his past self from the original film. "Part II" became notable for its 2015 setting and predictions of technology such as hoverboards.
BULLET::::- 1990 "Back to the Future Part III" as George Douglas McFly
__answers__: one thousand, eight hundred and eighty-five
one thousand eight hundred and eighty five
